net.rithms.riot.api.request.ratelimit

Class DefaultRateLimitHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.rithms.riot.api.request.ratelimit.DefaultRateLimitHandler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    RateLimitHandler
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BufferedRateLimitHandler

    public class DefaultRateLimitHandler
extends java.lang.Object
implements RateLimitHandler
    This is the default RateLimitHandler. It keeps track of rate limits when they are exceeded and prevents further requests from being fired if they would violate a known rate limit.

    If you want to keep the functionality of this DefaultRateLimitHandler but want to extend it, you can simply inherit this class and call the super methods like this: 

     public class CustomRateLimitHandler extends DefaultRateLimitHandler {
        @Override
        public void onRequestAboutToFire(Request request) throws RespectedRateLimitException {
                super.onRequestAboutToFire(request);
                // Your code here
        }

        @Override
        public void onRequestDone(Request request) {
                super.onRequestDone(request);
                // Your code here
        }
 }
    Author:
    Daniel 'Linnun' Figge

    • Method Detail

      • onRequestAboutToFire

        public void onRequestAboutToFire(Request request)
                          throws RespectedRateLimitException
        Description copied from interface: RateLimitHandler
        This method is called for every request before it is fired to the Riot API. Here you get the chance to respect rate limits and decide to not fire the request by throwing a RespectedRateLimitException instead.
        Specified by:
        onRequestAboutToFire in interface RateLimitHandler
        Throws:
        RespectedRateLimitException - If the RateLimitHandler decides that a request should not be fired

      • onRequestDone

        public void onRequestDone(Request request)
        Description copied from interface: RateLimitHandler
        This method is called for every request after it has finished. Here you get the chance to check the request's response and use its header fields to handle your rate limiting logic.
        Specified by:
        onRequestDone in interface RateLimitHandler
